steps.title: Wash the soybeans.
steps.content: Wash the soybeans. For the natto, you’ll need 4 cups (800 g) of soybeans. Place the beans in a colander or strainer, and rinse them thoroughly under cold water in the sink. Shake the beans well afterward to remove the excess moisture. [1] X Research source As you rinse the soybeans, remove any shrunken or discolored beans.

steps.title: Soak the beans overnight.
steps.content: Soak the beans overnight. After you’ve rinsed the soybeans, place them in a large pot. Cover the beans with 12 cups (2.8 l) of cold water to create a ratio of 3 parts water to 1 part beans so the beans have room to expand. Allow the beans to soak for 9 to 12 hours. [2] X Research source During colder months, you may need to soak the beans longer, so it may take as many as 15 to 20 hours.

steps.title: Drain the beans.
steps.content: Drain the beans. When the beans have finished soaking, dump them into a colander or strainer. Shake well to remove all of the excess moisture. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Transfer the beans to a large pot.
steps.content: Transfer the beans to a large pot. Once the beans are drained, place them in a large pot. Use a stainless steel, enameled, or other non-reactive pot because reactive materials may alter the taste and color of the natto. [4] X Research source

steps.title: Cover the beans with water and cook them until they’re soft.
steps.content: Cover the beans with water and cook them until they’re soft. Pour enough water into the pot to completely cover the beans. Place the pot on the stove, and bring it to a boil over high heat. Once it’s boiling, turn the heat down to medium and allow the beans to simmer for 9 hours. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Strain the beans.
steps.content: Strain the beans. When the soybeans are finished cooking, place a colander or strainer in the sink. Pour the beans into the colander and shake well to remove all of the excess water. [6] X Research source

steps.title: Place the beans in a sterilized pot.
steps.content: Place the beans in a sterilized pot. From this point in the natto-making process, it’s crucial that all of the containers and utensils you use are sterilized or mold and bacteria may develop. Boil a pot in water on high heat for 10 minutes to sterilize it. Dry it with a clean towel, and then add the beans to it. [7] X Research source Boil any spoons or other utensils that you’ll be using to mix as well.

steps.title: Combine the nattomoto powder and water.
steps.content: Combine the nattomoto powder and water. To make the natto, you’ll need nattomoto powder, which contains natto spores. Use the special spoon that comes with the powder to add one spoonful of the spores to a small sterilized bowl. Add 2 teaspoons (10 ml) of boiled water to the powder, and stir the mixture with a sterilized spoon until the powder dissolves. [8] X Research source Nattomoto powder is also known as natto spores or natto starter. You can purchase it from Japanese grocery stores and online retailers.

steps.title: Pour the natto spore solution over the beans.
steps.content: Pour the natto spore solution over the beans. Once the nattomoto powder has dissolved, cover the beans with the solution. Use a sterilized spoon to stir the beans and solution together so they’re fully combined. [9] X Research source

steps.title: Preheat the oven.
steps.content: Preheat the oven. To finish the natto, you’ll need to warm the beans in the oven for several hours. Set the temperature to 200°F (93°C) and allow it to preheat fully. [10] X Research source If your oven temperature doesn’t go as low as 200°F (93°C), use the lowest heat setting possible. You can even go as low as 100°F (38°C) if possible.

steps.title: Add the beans to oven-safe jars.
steps.content: Add the beans to oven-safe jars. Use a sterilized spoon to add a thin layer of beans to the bottom of 3 to 4 oven-safe glass jar. If any of the beans fall onto the counter or table during the transfer, discard them. [11] X Research source Make sure that the jars you use have lids. Sterilize the jars in boiling water before filling them.

steps.title: Cover the jars with cheesecloth and the lids.
steps.content: Cover the jars with cheesecloth and the lids. When the beans are in the jars, place a piece of sterilized cheesecloth over each one. Next, place the lids on the jars, closing them tightly. [12] X Research source

steps.title: Place in the oven to ferment for 24 hours.
steps.content: Place in the oven to ferment for 24 hours. Once they’re closed, place the covered jars in the preheated oven. Allow the beans to ferment in the oven for 22 to 24 hours. [13] X Research source You can also place the jars in a food dehydrator to ferment the beans.

steps.title: Allow the natto to cool.
steps.content: Allow the natto to cool. When the beans are finished fermenting, remove the jars from the oven. Let them cool for at least two hours. [14] X Research source

steps.title: Remove the cheesecloth and recover the jars with lids.
steps.content: Remove the cheesecloth and recover the jars with lids. Once the beans are cooled, remove the lids from the jars and discard the cheesecloth. Replace the lids on the jars so they’re tightly closed once more. [15] X Research source

steps.title: Refrigerate the natto overnight.
steps.content: Refrigerate the natto overnight. When the jars are recovered, place them in the refrigerator. Let them chill at least overnight or up to 3 to 4 days. [16] X Research source Natto are often served as part of a Japanese breakfast. It can also be incorporated into your meals in other interesting ways .
